abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Industrial
            Development Project for Nepal was marginally satisfactory.
            The project achieved its main objective, its impact on
            institutional development was modest, sustainability is
            uncertain at this time, and both the Bank and Borrower
            performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, investment lending projects in
            countries with less developed financial and industrial
            sectors should be kept simple with a limited number of
            components. Second, credit lines through DFIs for
            encouraging industrial investments should avoid putting in
            micro-management conditionalities, as they may violate
            normal banking instincts and principles. Third, implementing
            DFIs should be allowed to charge market rates of interest
            where a competitive lending environment exists. Lastly,
            foreign equity participation with management assistance for
            DFIs in developing countries should be encouraged.
